problem_text: a) Let G be a finite non-abelian group, and Z(G) its centre. One can associate a graph ΓG with G as follows: take G\Z(G) as vertices of ΓG and join two vertices x and y if xy ̸= yx. Let H be a finite non-abelian group such that ΓG ∼= ΓH. If H is simple, is it true that G ∼= H? Comment of 2009: This is true for groups with disconnected prime graphs (L. Wang, W. Shi, Commun. Algebra, 36 (2008), 523–528). A. Abdollahi, S. Akbari, H. R. Maimani
answer: a) Yes, it is mod CFSG (Ch. Khan’, G. Ch`en’, S. Go, Siberian Math. J., 49, no. 6 (2008), 1138–1146, for sporadic simple groups; A. Abdollahi, H. Shahverdi, J. Algebra, 357 (2012), 203–207, for alternating groups; R. M. Solomon, A. J. Woldar, J. Group Theory, 16, no. 6 (2013), 793–824, for simple groups of Lie type).
